eng_pos_or_descriptor: Where a fall (or rise) in the long-run equilibrium exchange rate causes the actual exchange rate to fall (or rise) by a greater amount before eventually moving back to the new long-run equilibrium level.
The system under which the government allows the exchange rate to be determined.

A country's exchange rate adjusted for changes in the domestic currency prices of its exports relative to the foreign currency prices of its imports. If a country's prices rise (fall) relative to those of its trading partners, its real exchange rate will rise (fall) relative to the nominal exchange rate.
An increase in the value of a nation's currency in foreign exchange markets; an increase in the rate of exchange for foreign currencies.
A decrease in the value of a nation's currency in foreign exchange markets; a decrease in the rate of exchange for foreign currencies.
Any factor other than the rate of exchange that determines a currency's demand and supply in the foreign exchange market.
A tax levied on the production of a specific product or on the quantity of the product purchased.
A measure of how easy it is for someone to be prevented from consuming a good. This is used for classifying public goods.
The practice of a labour union of restricting the supply of skilled union labour to increase the wages received by union members; the policies typically employed by a craft union.
An expenditure by government resulting directly in the employment of economic resources and in the absorption by government of the goods and services those resources produce; a government purchase.
The process of leaving a job and searching for another one as a means of improving one's working conditions.
Money supply that does not depend on the demand for money but is set by the authorities.
A variable whose value is determined independently of the model of which it is part.
An industry whose firms earn economic profits and for which an increase in output occurs as new firms enter the industry.
The line on an isoquant map that traces the minimum-cost combinations of two factors as output increases. It is drawn on the assumption that both factors can be varied. It is thus a long-run path.
An increase in government purchases of goods and services, a decrease in net taxes, or some combination of the two for the purpose of increasing aggregate demand and expanding real output.
The anticipations of consumers, firms, and others about future economic conditions.
A (short-run) Phillips curve whose position depends on the expected rate of inflation.

The increase in profit a firm anticipates it will obtain by purchasing capital (or engaging in research and development); expressed as a percentage of the total cost of the investment (or R&D) activity.
Total cost of expenses.

eng: Expenditure changing from depreciation: the income effect
eng_pos_or_descriptor: increasing / Where depreciation, via the substitution effect, will alter the demand for imports and exports, and this will, via the multiplier, affect the level of national income and hence the demand for imports.

eng: Expenditure changing from deflation: the income effect
eng_pos_or_descriptor: reducing / Where deflationary policies lead to a reduction in national income and hence a reduction in the demand for imports.

eng: Expenditure switching from deflation: the substitution effect
eng_pos_or_descriptor: Where deflationary policies lead to a reduction in inflation and thus cause a switch in expenditure away from imports and also towards exports.

eng: Expenditure switching from depreciation: the substitution effect
eng_pos_or_descriptor: Where a lower exchange rate reduces the price of exports and increases the price of imports. This will increase the sale of exports and reduce the sale of imports.
The method that adds all expenditures made for final goods and services to measure the gross domestic product.
The monetary payment a firm must make to an outsider to obtain a resource.
The payments to outside suppliers of inputs.
Government payments to domestic producers to enable them to reduce the price of a good or service to foreign buyers.
An upward-sloping curve that shows the amount of a product that domestic firms will export at each world price that is above the domestic price.
A sale of a good or service that increases the amount of foreign currency flowing to a nation's citizens, firms, and government.
The value placed on a coin or piece of paper money, e.g. cents and rands in South Africa or cents and dollars in America.
The value of goods and services at the prices received by sellers.
The bargaining system in which the prices of the various factors of production are determined.
Payment that flows to the economic factors of production. Profit is paid to entrepreneurship ability, rent to capital and labour while wages are paid to workers.
The tendency for international trade to reduce factor price inequalities both between and within countries.
The inputs into the production of goods and services: labour, land and raw materials, and capital.
The price of a product that enables its pro-ducer to obtain a normal profit and that is equal to the average total cost of producing it.
The false notion that what is true for the individual (or part) is necessarily true for the group (or whole).

The fact that technological advance, coupled with a price-inelastic and relatively constant demand, has made agriculture a declining industry; also, the tendency for farm income to fluctuate sharply from year to year.
Anything that is money because government has decreed it to be money even if it has no intrinsic value.
Goods that have been purchased for final use and not for resale or further processing or manufacturing
Services that have been purchased for final use and not for resale or further processing or manufacturing.
The record of the flows of money into and out of the country for the purposes of investment or as deposits in banks and other financial institutions.

eng: Financial account of the balance of payments
eng_pos_or_descriptor: The record of the flows of money into and out of the country for the purposes of investment or as deposits in banks and other financial institutions.
Money that is used in a business.
When an increase in government borrowing diverts money away from the private sector.
The removal of or relaxation of legal rules and regulations governing the activities of financial institutions.

Where employers can vary their wage costs by changing the composition of their workforce or the terms on which workers are employed. This implies it is easy to hire and fire and to increase and reduce wages.
The general name for financial institutions (banks, building societies, etc.) which act as a means of channelling funds from depositors to borrowers.
The use of demand management policy (fiscal or monetary) to smooth out cyclical fluctuations in the economy. This is countercyclical policy to counteract the business cycle.
An organization that employs resources to produce a good or service for profit and owns and operates one or more plants.
The solution of correcting a specific market distortion by ensuring that the whole economy operates under conditions of social efficiency.
Where a firm charges each consumer for each unit the maximum price which that consumer is willing to pay for that unit. This reduces consumer surplus and increases producer surplus.
When a firm gains from being the first one to take action.
The implementation and respect of a fiscal policy.

Policy to affect aggregate demand by altering the balance between government expenditure and taxation. It also includes how the spending is financed (i.e. taxing versus borrowing).
Changes in government spending and tax collections designed to achieve a full-employment and non-inflationary domestic output; also called discretionary fiscal policy.

A group of eight major nations (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, United Kingdom, and United States) whose leaders meet regularly to discuss common economic problems and try to coordinate economic policies.
The extra output that trading partners obtain through specialisation of production and exchange of goods and services.
A means of analysing the pricing behaviour of oligopolies that uses the theory of strategy associated with games such as chess and bridge.
Gross domestic product.
Actual gross domestic product minus potential output; may be either a positive amount (a positive GDP gap) or a negative amount (a negative GDP gap).
Actual gross domestic product minus potential output; may be either a positive amount (a positive GDP gap) or a negative amount (a negative GDP gap).
A price index for all the goods and services that make up the gross domestic product to assess whether there has been a real rise or fall in GDP from one year to another.
The combined accumulated debt of central and local government.

xho: intsalelamali karhulumente ngokubanzi; intsalela karhulumente ngokubanzi
eng_pos_or_descriptor: The combined deficit of central and local government.

The lack of ability or willingness of people to move to jobs in other parts of the country.
An inferior good whose demand increases as its price decreases as a result of a positive income effect larger than the normal negative substitution effect.

xho: iGini rashiyo; umlinganiselo wokungalingani ngokoqoqosho kaGini
eng_pos_or_descriptor: The area between the Lorenz curve and the 45° line divided by the total area under the 45° line. It is a measure of inequality. 1 would represent perfect inequality, whereas 0 would represent perfect equality.
The value of all goods and services produced within the country over a given period of time, usually 12 months.
GDP plus net income from abroad.
This is currency and gold held by the central bank or government for the purpose of intervening in the [foreign exchange market]. It forms part of their net foreign assets.
The system whereby countries' exchange rates were fixed in terms of a certain amount of gold and whereby balance of payments deficits were paid in gold.
The rate of saving that maximises the level of long-run consumption.
Controlling a symptom of a problem or only one part of the problem will not cure the problem: it will simply mean that the part that is being controlled now becomes a poor indicator of the problem.
A government security paying a fixed sum of money each year. It is redeemed by the government on its maturity date at its face value.

Inefficiencies in resource allocation caused by problems in the operation of the public sector (government), specifically, rent-seeking pressure by special-interest groups, short-sighted political behaviour, limited and bundled choices, and bureaucratic line.
A situation where government owns assets.

Expenditures by government for goods and services that government consumes in providing public goods and for public (or social) capital that has a long lifetime; the expenditures of all governments in the economy for those final goods and services.
Total expenditures by government.
from a tax on a good / The total tax revenue earned by the government from sales of a good.
A measure of a firm's size relative to market size used as an indicator of market power.
Differentiated goods.
holding company / Differentiated products.
Where the parent company holds interests in a number of subsidiary companies.
The original value of money the firm paid for factors it owns upon which the present value of assets and depreciation allowances are calculated.
When a firm enters an industry to take advantage of temporarily high profits and then leaves again as soon as the high profits have been exhausted.
Goods that are identical in terms of their properties, specifications and quality.
An oligopoly in which the firms produce a standardised product.
Products that are identical.
An equal treatment of people in similar situations.
The merger into a single firm of two firms producing the same product and selling it in the same geographic market.
A group of people living together as a family in shared accommodation and with common domestic expenses.
The income available for households to spend: i.e. personal incomes after deducting taxes on incomes and adding benefits.
The qualifications, skills and expertise that contribute to a worker's productivity.
The denial of equal access to productivity-enhancing education and training to members of particular groups.
Any expenditure undertaken to improve the education, skills, health, or mobility of workers, with an expectation of greater productivity and thus a positive return on the investment.
HDI / A composite index made up of three elements: an index for life expectancy, an index for school enrolment and adult literacy, and an index for GDP per capita in. purchasing power parity (PPP).

A very rapid inflation which is usually characterised by price increases of over 50% per month and resulting in the fall of value for money as a medium of exchange and affecting the productive economic activity.
A tentative explanation of cause and effect that requires testing.
A measure of a firm's size relative to market size used as an indicator of market power.

Homogenous products

The problem of identifying the relationship between two variables (e.g. price and quantity demanded) from the evidence when it is not known whether or how the variables have been affected by other determinants. For example, it is difficult to identify the shape of a demand curve simply by observing price and quantity when it is not known whether changes in other determinants have shifted the demand curve.
International Monetary Fund.

xho: ukungabi nakutshintsha; ukungabi nakuhanjiswa; ukungabi nakuguquka

In fiscal policy the time taken from the implementation of the policy until the policy starts taking effect.
A market situation in which each firm perceives it has the ability to influence the equilibrium price of its own product.
In fiscal policy the time taken from the decision until the policy is implemented.

xho: iindleko eziqukiweyo; iindleko ezingathanga ngqo; iindleko ezingeyomali ngqo;

The competition that domestic firms en-counter from the products and services of foreign producers.
A downsloping curve showing the amount of a product that an economy will import at each world price below the domestic price.
Import tariffs
A limit imposed by a nation on the quantity (or total value) of a good that may be imported during some period of time.
A trade and economic policy based on the premise that a developing country should attempt to substitute products which it imports (mostly finished goods) with locally produced products.
Z / Spending by individuals, firms, and governments for goods and services produced in foreign nations.

A reward or penalty designed to induce one set of economic agents to act in such a way as to produce results that another economic agent wants.

When the price increases, supply increases, but consumers will purchase the commodity in smaller quantities. Conversely, when the price decreases, consumers will buy in large quantities but supply will decrease.
A compensation structure that ties worker pay directly to performance. Such plans include piece rates, bonuses, stock options, commissions, and profit sharing.
The distribution of the burden of tax between sellers and buyers.
A situation where there is growth in GDP without an associated increase in employment.
The rate of return of an investment: the discount rate that makes the net present value of an investment equal to zero.
Where a group of currencies pegged to each other jointly float against other currencies.
Where the production of more of one good leads to the production of more of another.
Where a firm purchases supplies and produces both components and finished products as they are required. This minimises stock-holding and its associated costs.
The philosophical, ideological, and analytical views pertaining to Keynesian economics.
The demand curve for a non-collusive oligopolist, which is based on the assumption that rivals will match a price decrease and will ignore a price increase.
People's physical and mental talents and efforts that are used to help produce goods and services.
Persons 16 years of age and older who are not in institutions and who are employed or are unemployed and seeking work.
Total output divided by the quantity of labour employed to produce it; the average product of labour or output per hour of work.

eng_pos_or_descriptor: The Mandan idea that the economic value of any commodity is determined solely by the amount of labour that is required to produce it.
A group of workers organized to advance the interests of the group (to increase wages, shorten the hours worked, improve working conditions, and so on).
ratio / The percentage of the working-age population that is actually in the labour force.
A product requiring a relatively large amount of labour to be produced.

xho: ukuba nokumelana neemfuno kwabasebenzi; ukuba nokumelana neemo kwabasebenzi
eng_pos_or_descriptor: An economic situation which permits flexibility of the amount of people employed and their wages.
A curve relating government tax rates and tax revenues and on which a particular tax rate (between zero and 100 percent) maximises tax revenues.
Capitalism.
A product requiring a relatively large amount of land to be produced.
Trade can benefit all countries if they specialise in the goods in which they have a comparative advantage.
The principle that, other things equal, an increase in a product's price will reduce the quantity of it demanded, and conversely for a decrease in price.

xho: umgaqo olawula ukuhla kwemveliso; umthetho wokucutheka kwengeniso
eng_pos_or_descriptor: marginal / When one or more factors are held fixed, there will come a point beyond which the extra output from additional units of the variable factor will diminish.
The principle that as the production of a good increases, the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit rises.
Where a monopolist (or oligopolist) charges a price below the short-run profit maximising level in order to deter new entrants.
Restriction of the maximum loss to a predetermined amount for the owners (stockholders) of a corporation. The maximum loss is the amount they paid for their shares of stock.

xho: inkampani elikhusi kuxandava lwelahleko; inkampani eyahlula inkampani kumniniyo
eng_pos_or_descriptor: An unincorporated business whose owners are protected by limited liability.

The ease with which an asset can be converted quickly into cash with little or no loss of purchasing power. Money is said to be perfectly liquid, whereas other assets have a lesser degree of liquidity.
The demand for holding assets in the form of money.
The proportion of a bank's total assets held in liquid form.

xho: ukwehla komdla wokutyala imali; uloyiko lwelahleko kutyalomali
eng_pos_or_descriptor: The absorption of any additional money supply into idle balances at very low rates of interest, leaving aggregate demand unchanged.
Money available for lending and borrowing.
Shocks that result from change in aggregate demand or aggregate supply and affect the macroeconomy, i.e. output, inflation and employment.
The branch of economics that studies economic aggregates (grand totals): e.g. the overall level of prices, output and employment in the economy.
dirty floating / A system of flexible exchange rates but where the government intervenes to prevent excessive fluctuations or even to achieve an unofficial target exchange rate.
A system of flexible exchange rates but where the government intervenes to prevent excessive fluctuations or even to achieve an unofficial target exchange rate.
The decisions that management of the firm has the sole right to make; often enumerated in the labour contract (work agreement) between a labour union and a firm.
Extra or additional.
The comparison of marginal ("extra" or "additional") benefits and marginal costs, usually for decision making.
The extra (additional) benefit of consuming 1 more unit of some good or service; the change in total benefit when 1 more unit is consumed.
The amount of extra capital (in money terms) required to produce a R1 increase in national output.
The excess of utility from the consumption of one more unit of a good (MU) over the price paid: MCS = MU - P.

MC / The extra (additional) cost of producing 1 more unit of output; equal to the change in total cost divided by the change in output (and, in the short run, to the change in total variable cost divided by the change in output).

The rate of return of an investment: the discount rate that makes the net present value of an investment equal to zero.
The extra output gained by the employment of one more unit of the variable factor: MPP = ATPP/AQv.

eng_pos_or_descriptor: An economy where economic decisions are made partly by the government and partly through the market.
An economy where economic decisions are made partly by the government and partly through the market.
The willingness and ability of labour to move to another job.

xho: imanitharizim; ukujonga ezoqoqosho ngeliso lemali; utyekelo emalini
eng_pos_or_descriptor: The macroeconomic view that the main cause of changes in aggregate output and the price level is fluctuations in the money supply; espoused by advocates of a monetary rule.

Notes and coin outside the central bank.
Monetary policy that focuses on controlling the monetary base (as opposed to broad liquidity).
The number of times greater the expansion of money supply is than the expansion of the monetary base that caused it.
A central bank's changing of the money supply to influence interest rates and assist the economy in achieving price stability, full employment, and economic growth.
Items of money that can be spent directly (cash and money in cheque-book/debit-card accounts).

The position resulting from everyone making their optimal decision based on their assumptions about their rivals' decisions. Without collusion, there is no incentive for any firm to move from this position.
The accumulated budget deficits (less surpluses) over the years: the total amount of government borrowing.
E / Aggregate demand in the Keynesian model: i.e. Cd
Total income earned by resource suppliers for their contributions to gross domestic product; equal to the gross domestic product minus nonincome charges, minus net foreign factor income.
The techniques used to measure the overall production of the economy and other related variables for the nation as a whole.

xho: ushishino oluphantsi kukarhulumente; ushishino olulawulwa ngurhulumente
eng_pos_or_descriptor: State-owned industries that produce goods or services that are sold in the market.
The level of output in monetarist analysis where the vertical long-run aggregate supply curve (the long run Phillip's curve) cuts the horizontal axis.
The level of equilibrium employment which is present at the natural level of output.
A situation where long-run average costs would be lower if an industry were under monopoly than if it were shared between two or more competitors.

The rate of unemployment at which there is no excess or deficiency of demand for labour, this means there is no cyclical unemployment. It is still possible to have structural and frictional unemployment at this point.
Factors of production provided by nature.
When a firm wishing to reduce its workforce does so by not replacing those who leave or retire.

This is a good that has to be consumed, e.g. food and water, i.e. without which we cannot live.
Goods that have to be consumed, e.g. food and water, for survival.
A situation in which actual gross domestic product is less than potential output.
A combined system of tax and benefits. As people earn more they gradually lose their benefits until beyond a certain level they begin paying taxes.
Inverse relationship.
An economy that exports and imports goods and services. Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
A place of employment in which the employer may hire nonunion workers and the workers need not become members of a labour union.
The sale (or purchase) by the authorities of government securities in the open market in order to reduce (or increase) money supply or influence interest rates
The amount of other products that must be forgone or sacrificed to produce a unit of a product.

The optimal size of a currency area is the one that maximises the benefits from having a single currency relative to the costs. If the area were increased or decreased in size, the costs would rise relative to the benefits.
A tariff that reduces the level of imports to the point where the country's marginal social cost equals marginal social benefit.
A measure of utility that ranks preferences, but does not use an absolute scale. For example 4 utils is larger than 2, we cannot say 4 utils is twice the size of 2 utils.

xho_pos_or_descriptor: OPEC / umbutho wamazwe athumela ipetroliyam ngaphandle

eng_pos_or_descriptor: The assumption that factors other than those being considered are held constant.

The product of a firm, following the processing of the required inputs.

Those out of work or employed on a casual, part-time or short-term basis, who have little or no power to influence wages or employment.
The amount of extra capital (in money terms) required to produce a R1 increase in national output.
Costs arising from the general running of an organisation, and only indirectly related to the level of output.
Pieces of paper used as a medium of exchange; e.g South African Reserve Bank notes or Federal Reserve Reserve notes in the United States.
A situation where paired-choice voting by majority rule fails to provide a consistent ranking of society's preferences for public goods or services.
Where changes in production or consumption can make at least one person better off without making anyone worse off.
Where all possible Pareto improvements have been made: where, therefore, it is impossible to make anyone better off without making someone else worse off.
The idea that year after year a specific output of a farm product should enable a farmer to acquire a constant amount of non-agricultural goods and services.

The ratio of the price received by farmers from the sale of an agricultural commodity to the prices of other goods paid by them; usually expressed as a percentage; used as a rationale for price supports.
A market with just a few buyers or employers.
Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Pay As You Earn.
